title: Leslie Balfour-Melville
text:
Leslie Balfour-Melville (9 March 1854 – 17 July 1937), born Leslie Balfour, was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> <a href="amateur%20sportsman">amateur sportsman</a>, serving as captain, <a href="opening%20batsman">opening batsman</a>, and <a href="wicket-keeper">wicket-keeper</a> for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20cricket%20team">Scotland national cricket team</a>.
Balfour-Melville was also an international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player, <a href="tennis%20player">tennis player</a>, <a href="ice%20skater">ice skater</a>, <a href="curling">curler</a>, <a href="long-jumper">long-jumper</a>, and player of <a href="English%20billiards">English billiards</a>. He was a prolific <a href="golf">golf</a> medal winner, winning <a href="The%20Amateur%20Championship">The Amateur Championship</a>, at <a href="St%20Andrews">St Andrews</a> in 1895. He also held several administrative positions within national <a href="Sports%20governing%20bodies">governing bodies</a>. He was President of the <a href="Scottish%20Rugby%20Union">Scottish Rugby Union</a>, President of the <a href="Scottish%20Cricket%20Union">Scottish Cricket Union</a>, and Captain of <a href="The%20Royal%20and%20Ancient%20Golf%20Club%20of%20St%20Andrews">The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews</a> in 1906.
Balfour-Melville was an inaugural inductee into the <a href="Scottish%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Scottish Sports Hall of Fame</a> in 2002.
Biography.
Balfour was born in <a href="Bonnington%2C%20Edinburgh">Bonnington, Edinburgh</a>, on 9 March 1854 the son of James Balfour Melville (1815–1898) and his wife, Eliza Ogilvy Heriot Maitland (1821–1887).
He was educated at the <a href="Edinburgh%20Academy">Edinburgh Academy</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>, he became a <a href="Scots%20law">lawyer</a> by profession, rising to be a <a href="Writer%20to%20the%20Signet">Writer to the Signet</a>. In 1893 the family changed its name to Balfour-Melville when his father succeeded to the estate of <a href="Mount%20Melville">Mount Melville</a> near <a href="St%20Andrews">St Andrews</a>, <a href="Fife">Fife</a>. His Edinburgh residence was at 53 Hanover Street in <a href="New%20Town%2C%20Edinburgh">Edinburgh's New Town</a>.
His son <a href="James%20Balfour-Melville">James</a> also played cricket for Scotland before losing his life in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>.
Balfour-Melville died in <a href="North%20Berwick">North Berwick</a>, <a href="East%20Lothian">East Lothian</a>, on 16 July 1937. He is buried with his parents in the family tomb in the south-west corner of <a href="Greyfriars%20Kirkyard">Greyfriars Kirkyard</a> close to the Robertson mausoleum. On his grave he is named simply as Leslie Melville.
Cricket career.
Playing for the <a href="The%20Grange%2C%20Edinburgh%20%28cricket%20and%20sports%20club%29">Grange</a>, he debuted against the <a href="Free%20Foresters">Free Foresters</a> in 1874. He played eighteen matches for the national side over 36 years. He captained Scotland in their first match against <a href="Ireland%20national%20cricket%20team">Ireland</a> after the formation of the 2nd <a href="Scottish%20Cricket%20Union">Scottish Cricket Union</a>, and was the first President of the Scottish Cricket Union to play for the national side. During his career he scored 46 <a href="Century%20%28cricket%29">centuries</a>.

Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
Leslie Balfour, as he was then, played for <a href="Edinburgh%20Academicals">Edinburgh Academicals</a>.
International career.
He was capped once in 1872.
Referee career.
He refereed the East v West district match in 1880.
Administrative career.
Balfour-Melville became the 21st <a href="President%20of%20the%20Scottish%20Rugby%20Union">President of the Scottish Rugby Union</a>. He served the 1893–94 term in office.
Tennis career.
Balfour won the Scottish Lawn Tennis Championships in 1879.
